p.text: A reference in this Part to a person who fails to attend for jury service is a reference to a person who—
is duly summoned to attend at a court or coronial inquest;
fails to attend on the first or on any subsequent day on which the persons attendance is required; and
is not duly excused from that attendance.
[subs (1) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

Where the sheriff notifies a person of an alteration in the time or place at which the person is required by a summons to attend for jury service, the person does not fail to attend for jury service for the purposes of this Part if the person attends at the altered time or place as so notified to the person.
[subs (2) insrt Act 34 of 1981 Sch 1 ; am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,675] s 61 Offences relating to responding to questionnaire

leg:heading.title: Offences relating to responding to questionnaire

p.text: A person who is sent a notice under section 13 about the person's inclusion on a supplementary jury roll and who is required to return to the sheriff the questionnaire included in the notice must not, except with good cause, fail to do so within the time specified in the notice.
[subs (1) subst Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
The person must not, except with good cause, return such a questionnaire to the sheriff without complete answers to all of the questions in it.
The person must not return such a questionnaire to the sheriff if it contains any answer or other information that the person knows to be false or misleading in a material respect.
Maximum penalty: 10 penalty units.
[s 61 subst Act 4 of 1996 s 4 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,680] s 62 Supply of false or misleading information to sheriff

leg:heading.title: Supply of false or misleading information to sheriff

p.text: A person must not provide any information to the sheriff that the person knows to be false or misleading in a material respect:
when claiming to be disqualified from serving as a juror or to be ineligible to serve as a juror or to be entitled as of right to be exempted from serving as a juror, or
when claiming otherwise that the person is not or will not be available for jury service.

A person must not cause or permit any representation the person knows to be false or misleading in a material respect to be made to the sheriff on the person's behalf, or on behalf of another person, for the purpose of evading jury service.
Maximum penalty: 10 penalty units.
[s 62 subst Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,685] s 62A Failure to inform sheriff of disqualification or ineligibility

leg:heading.title: Failure to inform sheriff of disqualification or ineligibility

p.text: A person summoned to attend at a court or coronial inquest who knows that he or she is disqualified from serving as a juror or ineligible to serve as a juror must, before the day on which the person's attendance is required, inform the sheriff of that fact and the reason for the disqualification or ineligibility.
Maximum penalty: 10 penalty units.
[s 62A insrt Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,690] s 63 Failure to attend for jury service

leg:heading.title: Failure to attend for jury service

p.text: Subject to sections 64 and 66 , a person who fails to attend for jury service contravenes this section and is liable to a penalty not exceeding 20 penalty units.
[subs (1) am Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
In any proceedings for an offence under this section, a document purporting to be signed by the sheriff and to certify:
that a specified person is recorded as having failed to attend for jury service, or
that a specified person has declined to be dealt with under section 64 ,
is evidence of the matter so certified.
[subs (2) insrt Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 2]
It is a defence to a prosecution for an offence under this section if the person prosecuted proves that the person had a reasonable excuse for his or her failure to attend for jury service.
[subs (3) insrt Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
[s 63 am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 20 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 7 ; Act 108 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,695] s 64 Procedure for failure to attend for jury service

leg:heading.title: Procedure for failure to attend for jury service

p.text: If a person fails to attend for jury service at a court or coronial inquest, a record of that fact is to be made on the relevant panel by order of the court, of the coroner holding the inquest or of any court in which trials for which the panel was prepared are held.
[subs (1) subst Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

The sheriff shall serve, on a person who is recorded under subsection (1) as having failed to attend for jury service, a notice to the effect that, if the person does not desire to have the matter referred to a court, the person—

pay to an officer specified in the notice at a place and within a time specified in the notice an amount of penalty equal to 10 penalty units prescribed for that failure if dealt with under this section; or
show cause to the sheriff within the time specified in the notice why a penalty should not be imposed for that failure.
[subs (2) am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
The sheriff may require a person who shows cause under subsection (2)(b) to verify the persons statements by statutory declaration.
[subs (3) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

If the sheriff determines that a person has not shown reasonable cause under subsection (2)(b) for the persons failure to attend for jury service, the sheriff shall inform that person accordingly and specify a further period of time within which the person may pay the amount of penalty referred to in subsection (2)(a) .
[subs (4) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
A person served with a notice under subsection (2) —
has the right to decline to be dealt with under this section; and

shall be deemed to have declined to be so dealt with if the person does not show reasonable cause under subsection (2)(b) for the persons failure to attend for jury service within the time specified in the notice and if the person fails to pay the relevant amount of penalty within the time specified in the notice or within such further time as may, under subsection (4) or in any particular case, be allowed by the sheriff.
[subs (5) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
Where the relevant amount of penalty is paid pursuant to subsection (2)(a) , no person shall be liable for any further proceedings for that failure to attend for jury service.
[subs (6) am Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,700] s 65 Imposition of penalty by judge for failure to attend for jury service at a court or jury pool

leg:heading.title: Imposition of penalty by judge for failure to attend for jury service at a court or jury pool

p.text: [s 65 rep Act 20 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 7]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,705] s 66 Penalty notices for failure to attend jury service

leg:heading.title: Penalty notices for failure to attend jury service

p.text: If it appears to the sheriff or a person prescribed by the regulations that a person has contravened section 61 , or has declined to be dealt with under section 64 in respect of a failure to attend for jury service, the sheriff or prescribed person may serve a penalty notice on the person.

A penalty notice is a notice to the effect that, if the person served does not wish to have the alleged contravention of section 61 or 63 dealt with by a court, the person may pay, within the time and to the person specified in the notice, the penalty of:
in the case of an alleged contravention of section 61 — 5 penalty units, or
in the case of an alleged contravention of section 63 — 15 penalty units.
[subs (2) subst Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
If the relevant penalty for the alleged offence is paid in accordance with this section, no person is liable to any further proceedings for the alleged offence.
[subs (3) am Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]

Payment in accordance with this section is not to be regarded as an admission of liability for the purposes of, nor is in any way to affect or prejudice, any civil claim, action or proceeding arising out of the same occurrence.
[subs (5) rep Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 3]
This section does not limit the operation of this or any other Act in relation to proceedings that may be taken in respect of offences.
[s 66 subst Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 2]
Any person who personates a juror is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: 50 penalty units.
[s 67 subst Act 51 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
A person must not inspect, or make available to any other person, a panel or card prepared for the purposes of this Act by the sheriff.
Maximum penalty: 10 penalty units.
[subs (1) subst Act 4 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
This section does not apply to anything inspected or made available to another person—
for the purposes of executing this Act.
[repealed ]
[repealed ]
[subs (2) am Act 15 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1]
[s 67A insrt Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,720] s 68 Disclosure etc of identity or address of juror

leg:heading.title: Disclosure etc of identity or address of juror

p.text: A person shall not, except in accordance with this Act, wilfully publish any material, broadcast any matter or otherwise disclose any information which is likely to lead to the identification of a juror or former juror in a particular trial or inquest.
Penalty: In the case of a corporation, $250,000; in any other case, 2 years imprisonment or 50 penalty units (or both).
[subs (1) am Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 5 , effective 1 January 2004]
Subsection (1) does not apply to the identification of a former juror with the consent of the former juror.
[s 68 subst Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1]
A reference in this section to the identification of a juror or former juror includes a reference to the disclosure of the address of the juror or former juror.

Subsection (1) does not apply to the disclosure of information by the sheriff to any of the following bodies or persons for the purposes of an investigation or prosecution of a contempt of court or an offence relating to a juror or a jury:
a court,
the New South Wales Crime Commission,
the Independent Commission Against Corruption,
the Police Integrity Commission,
the Australian Crime Commission,
the Director of Public Prosecutions,
the NSW Police Force,
the Australian Federal Police.
[subs (4) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 4 ; am Act 13 of 2003 Sch 1 , effective 30 June 2003 ; Act 62 of 2011 Sch 3.17, effective 6 January 2012]

Subsection (1) does not apply to the disclosure of information by the sheriff to a person in accordance with an authority granted by the Attorney General for the conduct of a research project into matters relating to juries or jurors.
[subs (5) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 4]
In this section:
includes any tribunal, authority or person having power to require the production of documents or the answering of questions.
[subs (6) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 4]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,725] s 68A Soliciting information from or harassing jurors or former jurors

leg:heading.title: Soliciting information from or harassing jurors or former jurors

p.text: A person must not solicit information from, or harass, a juror or former juror for the purpose of obtaining information about:
the deliberations of a jury, or
how a juror, or the jury, formed any opinion or conclusion in relation to an issue arising in a trial or coronial inquest.
Maximum penalty on indictment: imprisonment for 7 years.
[subs (1) subst Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]
The deliberations of a jury include statements made, opinions expressed, arguments advanced or votes cast by members of the jury in the course of their deliberations.

Subsection (1) does not prohibit a person from soliciting information from a juror or former juror in accordance with an authority granted by the Attorney-General for the conduct of a research project into matters relating to juries or jury service.

Subsection (1) does not prohibit any of the following bodies or persons from soliciting information from a juror or former juror for the purposes of an investigation or prosecution of a contempt of court or an offence relating to a juror or a jury:
a court,
the New South Wales Crime Commission,
the Independent Commission Against Corruption,
the Police Integrity Commission,
the Australian Crime Commission,
the Director of Public Prosecutions,
the NSW Police Force,
the Australian Federal Police.
[subs (4) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 2 and Sch 4 ; am Act 13 of 2003 Sch 1 , effective 30 June 2003 ; Act 62 of 2011 Sch 3.17, effective 6 January 2012]
Subsection (1) does not prohibit a juror from soliciting information from another member of the jury during a trial or coronial inquest.
[subs (4A) insrt Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]
In this section:
includes any tribunal, authority or person having power to require the production of documents or the answering of questions.
[subs (5) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 2 and Sch 4]
[s 68A insrt Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1]

An attempt by any person, whether lawyer, police officer, court official, journalist or any other member of the public to breach the privacy and confidentiality of jury deliberations runs the risk of offending against this provision. It is necessary, not only to ensure the finality of jury verdicts, but to ensure jurors or former jurors are not subject to pressure, harassment or otherwise in relation to their deliberations or the verdict itself: R v Rinaldi (1993) 30 NSWLR 605 at 612 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,730] s 68B Disclosure of information by jurors etc

leg:heading.title: Disclosure of information by jurors etc

p.text: A juror must not, except with the consent of or at the request of the judge or coroner, wilfully disclose to any person during the trial or coronial inquest information about:
the deliberations of the jury, or
how a juror, or the jury, formed any opinion or conclusion in relation to an issue arising in the trial or coronial inquest.
Maximum penalty: 20 penalty units.
[subs (1) subst Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]
A person (including a juror or former juror) must not, for a fee, gain or reward, disclose or offer to disclose to any person information about:
the deliberations of a jury, or
how a juror, or a jury, formed any opinion or conclusion in relation to an issue arising in a trial or coronial inquest.
Maximum penalty: 50 penalty units.
[subs (2) subst Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]
The deliberations of a jury include statements made, opinions expressed, arguments advanced or votes cast by members of the jury in the course of their deliberations.
[s 68B insrt Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1]
Subsection (1) does not prohibit a juror from disclosing information to another member of the jury during a trial or coronial inquest.
[subs (4) insrt Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,735] s 68C Inquiries by juror about trial matters prohibited

leg:heading.title: Inquiries by juror about trial matters prohibited

p.text: A juror for the trial of any criminal proceedings must not make an inquiry for the purpose of obtaining information about the accused, or any matters relevant to the trial, except in the proper exercise of his or her functions as a juror.
Maximum penalty: 50 penalty units or imprisonment for 2 years, or both.

This section applies in respect of a juror from the time the juror is sworn in as a juror and until the juror, or the jury of which the juror is a member, is discharged by the court having conduct of the proceedings.
This section does not prohibit a juror:
from making an inquiry of the court, or of another member of the jury, in the proper exercise of his or her functions as a juror, or
from making an inquiry authorised by the court.
Anything done by a juror in contravention of a direction given to the jury by the judge in the criminal proceedings is not a proper exercise by the juror of his or her functions as a juror.
For the purpose of this section, making an inquiry includes the following:
asking a question of any person,
conducting any research, for example, by searching an electronic database for information (such as by using the Internet),
viewing or inspecting any place or object,
conducting an experiment,
causing someone else to make an inquiry.
[s 68C insrt Act 102 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 , effective 15 December 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,740] s 69 Unlawful dismissal of or prejudice to employees summoned for jury service

leg:heading.title: Unlawful dismissal of or prejudice to employees summoned for jury service

p.text: An employer shall not dismiss a person in his or her employment or injure the person in his or her employment or alter his or her position to his or her prejudice by reason of the fact that the person is summoned to serve as a juror.
Penalty: 20 penalty units.
[subs (1) am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

In proceedings for an offence under subsection (1) , if all the facts constituting the offence other than the reason for the defendant's action are proved, the onus of proving that the dismissal, injury or alteration was not actuated by the reason alleged in the charge shall lie on the defendant.
Where an employer is convicted by a court of an offence under subsection (1) , the court may order—
the employer to pay the employee a specified sum by way of reimbursement for the salary or wages lost by the employee; and
that the employee be reinstated in his or her old or a similar position.
[subs (3) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
An order under subsection (3)(a) shall operate as an order against the employer for the payment of money under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 , and shall be enforceable as such an order under that Act.
[subs (4) am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 2; Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 2[2.43] , effective 4 December 2006]
An employer shall give effect to an order of the court under subsection (3)(b) .
Penalty: 20 penalty units.
[subs (5) am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1]

The amount of salary or wages that would have been payable to an employee in respect of any period that his or her employer fails to give effect to an order under subsection (3)(b) shall be recoverable, as a debt due to the employee by the employer, in any court of competent jurisdiction.
[subs (6) am Act 95 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
An employer shall not threaten a person employed by the employer with:
dismissal, or
injury in his or her employment, or
alteration of his or her position to his or her prejudice,
by reason of the fact that the person is summoned to serve as a juror.
Penalty: 20 penalty units.
[subs (7) insrt Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 15]

In proceedings for an offence under subsection (7), if all the facts constituting the offence other than the reason for the defendant's action are proved, the onus of providing that the threat was not actuated by the reason alleged in the charge lies on the defendant.
[subs (8) insrt Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 15]
A person can be prosecuted for and convicted of offences under both subsections (1) and (7) in relation to the same circumstances.
[subs (9) insrt Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 15]
In this section:
includes a person acting on behalf of the employer.
[subs (10) insrt Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 15]
[s 69 am Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 15]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [345,745] s 70 Directors, etc, liable where corporation commits offence

leg:heading.title: Directors, etc, liable where corporation commits offence

p.text: A person who is a director or an employee of a corporation which offends against this Act is guilty of the same offence, and liable to be punished as an individual guilty of that offence, if—
the offence committed by the corporation was committed with the knowledge of that person;
that person was in a position to influence the conduct of the corporation in relation to the commission of the offence by it; and
that person did not use all due diligence to prevent the commission of the offence by the corporation.
Except to the extent that this Act otherwise provides, proceedings for offences against this Act shall be disposed of in a summary manner before the Local Court.
[subs (1) am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2 , effective 7 July 2003 ; Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
Proceedings for an offence under section 68 by a corporation may be dealt with:
summarily before the Local Court, or
summarily before the Supreme Court in its summary jurisdiction.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 5 , effective 1 January 2004 ; am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

If proceedings for an offence under section 68 by a corporation are brought in the Local Court, the maximum monetary penalty that the Local Court may impose for the offence is $10,000, despite any higher maximum monetary penalty provided in respect of the offence by that section.
[subs (1B) insrt Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 5 , effective 1 January 2004 ; am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

Chapter 5 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 (which relates to the summary disposal of certain indictable offences unless an election is made to proceed on indictment) applies to and in respect of an offence under section 68A .
[subs (2) insrt Act 15 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act No 94 of 1999 Sch 4.34 ; Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2 , effective 7 July 2003]
[s 71 am Act 286 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 2]
